justification: “Finally, the Optimism hypothesis has the strongest empirical support, primarily from studies using the ‘Marks paradigm’ (Marks, 1951)… Participants were more likely to predict a marked card in the desirable condition and less likely in the undesirable condition compared to the neutral scenario (Irwin, 1953; Marks, 1951).”

“…we adapted a paradigm that calls for repeated mental simulation, the random generation task (Baddeley, 1966)… it has been adapted to explore the mental sampling process itself, such as stereotypes, and events with equal and unequal probabilities.”

“Their findings showed that… probability estimates were higher in the loss-money scenario and lower in the gain-money scenario… One possible explanation for this tendency is the concept of defensive pessimism (Norem & Cantor, 1986).”

“Pleskac and Hertwig (2014) and Hoffart et al. (2019) found that, under uncertainty, people tend to assign lower probability to higher reward… While not empirically tested in these studies, Pleskac and Hertwig (2014) argued that people would… think that larger losses would be less likely than smaller losses.”
